results.title: Easter around the world. Yrs. 7-10
results.brief_description: Easter is presented as a world wide festival to celebrate new life and the Christian belief in Christ’s rising from the dead. The program is in two parts: “The origins of Easter” and “Easter symbols” Many examples of festivals around the world are shown and some ideas for classroom activities suggested. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Easter around the world. Yrs. 5-7
results.brief_description: Broken into two parts, this video provides examples of activities for studies around the Easter period and shows different people across the globe celebrating Easter. “Origins of Easter” deals with the pre-Christian traditions, festivals, carnivals, Jewish Passover and Christian tradition. “Easter symbols” deals with light and dark, eggs, the origins of the Easter Rabbit, Easter food and the concept of new life.

results.title: East/west = Est/ouest
results.creator_credit: Yves Marmion, UGC YM, France 3 Cinema, Gala Films, Mate, NTV-Profit and Regis Wargnier
results.brief_description: At the cessation of World War II hostilities, Soviet authorities allowed Russian citizens in exile back to their mother country. The Government promised prosperity and freedom, but delivered hard-line Communism, repression, brutality and a depressed economy. “East/West” follows the trials of one couple that experience a violent and humiliating repatriation. Alexei Golovin is a Russian doctor who in 1946 returns to the Soviet Union with his French wife and young son. Almost instantaneously the two are brutalised by the violent regime, in particular Maire (Sandrine Bonnaire) who is accused of being an imperialist spy. Sent to a decrepit communal housing flat, Marie rages against her fate, but Alexie cautions patience and tolerance as he tries to believe in the Communist rules under which they endlessly suffer. “East/West” is effective in displaying Marie’s desperation and despondency with her new life, but as the plot convolutions evolve, the film at times loses its momentum. Catherine Deneuve plays a French actress who discovers Marie’s plight whilst touring a play in Russia and sets about assisting her escape. Directed by Regis Wargnier (A French woman, Indochine). In French and Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: East to west
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach. Edward John Eyre was the first white man to journey across the Nullabour Plain from the east coast to the west coast. He had originally organised and lead an expedition, beginning in Adelaide, that aimed to travel north through Australia’s centre. This attempt was hindered by mirages that prohibited him from finding a break in a series of lakes that would provide access to the north. Defeated by the desert yet determined not to return to Adelaide as a failure, he decided to attempt an east-west crossing that he had previously advised against. Accompanied by his friend John Baxter, his aboriginal guide Wylie, and two indigenous Australians, Eyre veered west. He persevered across the desolate and forbidding landscape, constantly searching for fresh water and shelter from the elements, as he headed for Perth. Unfortunately, Eyre and Wylie were the only two members of the group who eventually reached Perth following a tragic event that claimed the life of Baxter.

results.title: East to north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Presented by Bill Peach, this program uses reenactments to describe the trail taken by the expeditions of Ludwig Leichardt from the eastern settlements in New South Wales north to Port Essington in Northern Australia, documenting the challenges and hardships they faced along the way.

results.title: East Timor: from colonisation to independence
results.brief_description: After 400 years under the Portuguese and 25 years under the Indonesians, the East Timorese are finally free to determine their own future. This program has been designed as a teaching aid and is divided into ten segments with each segment providing a detailed historical overview of a particular period relating to the long and sometimes extremely violent struggle towards East Timor’s independence. Using television archival footage and newsreels, the program includes a look at the country under the Portuguese, tracing the key developments since 1974: the plans for decolonisation, the rise of nationalist groups and conflict between them, the reaction of the Indonesians, the invasion of 1975 and the subsequent farcical Act of Integration, the Dili Massacre, worldwide pressure for change, and the events surrounding the referendum of August 1999. Also includes footage of Jose Ramos Horta (Secretary General of Fretilin), Xanana Gusmau (leader of the guerilla force Falantil), Indonesia’s President Suharto and President Habibie, John Howard, along with many others who played an important role in the making of this very new and independent nation. Suitable for secondary and tertiary level students. Teacher notes included.

results.title: East Timor: birth of a nation
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Luigi Acquisto, Stella Zammataro and Andrew Sully
results.brief_description: In 1974 after 460 years of Portuguese rule, Fretilin, the revolutionary front for an independent East Timor, declared independence in the small nation. Ten days later Indonesia invaded. Fretilin and the resistance army fought the Indonesian military over the next 24 years, with over 250,000 people dying as a result of the occupation. In 1999, the East Timorese people voted overwhelmingly for independence, but as the Indonesian army and local militia withdrew, chaos ensued, razing the country to the ground. This two-part documentary recounts incredible stories from East Timor after the country is reborn as an independent nation. Episode one: Rosas story is about a young widow and mother of six, living in abject poverty with her children scattered in various orphanages. She saves for the fare to reunite her family for the first time expressing her hope for their future. Episode two: Lu Olos story is about a man who survived twenty years in the armed resistance. Having accepted an elevated rank, Lu Olo faces the difficulties in transitioning from guerilla fighter to politician.

results.title: East side story : the story of Soviet musicals
results.brief_description: The Iron Curtain countries were not known for their joie de vivre, but between the cracks of stark socialist realism, there somehow appeared a few films that offered their audiences escape, hope and hit songs. With lots of colourful clips from singing pig farmers, dancing sailors, happy housewives, socialist summer vacations, the cinderella factory girl and of course the singing tractor-drivers, this moving, hilarious and courageous story is thoughtfully told by the filmmakers and actors themselves.

results.title: East of the moon. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: Joy Whitby, Grasshopper, Sianel 4 Cymru, Sudwestfunk and Marc Evans
results.brief_description: The witch and the rainbow cat is the story of Rose, a young girl on an outing to the country with her parents. Rose enters a mysterious wood in which she discovers a strange little house full of bric-a-brac and curiosities. A stuffed cat watches her as she sees her reflection in a mirror which shows her what she will look like in the future. When the owner of the house arrives - a wizened old witch - she is told that she will have to be the witch’s servant for the rest of her life. The stuffed cat comes to life and offers to help Rose if she can solve a riddle. She manages to escape and rejoins her parents who laugh at her story. “The sea tiger” is the story of a tiger who tells the most outrageous lies and how his animal friends in the jungle try to put a stop to it. This video also includes the song “Think before you speak”, written by Neil Innes.
